instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3462: What is 820-3462? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Thermal error fans running high
threads.message:
The macbook boots up and runs. ASD EFI passes but ASD OS has 2 thermal errors "unknown result code -- test failed" and the fans are constantly running full speed.

This macbook had liquid damage, I replaced a couple of resistors near the SMC <RESISTOR>R5092</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R2502</RESISTOR> and ran a jumper from pin2 of <RESISTOR>R5092</RESISTOR> to <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> as that pad was gone. The only other corrosion I could find was a little inside the thunderbolt connectors.

I tried another heatsink and thermal paste and checked that <CHIP>U5570</CHIP> has 3.3V on pin1. Could this be a problem with the SMC?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Thermal error fans running high
threads.message:
Run HWMonitor and see if any temp goes crazy.
Try known good trackpad board and flex.
Also test it disconnecting camera.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Thermal error fans running high
threads.message:
I put the board in a spare chassis I have but the right io board is dodgy so it's left unconnected. Also left the camera disconnected.

Booted with a test macos and ran istat menus. It's hell slow and CPU is at 99%, temps are stable but the CPU die is not showing a temperature.[ATTACH alt="istat.jpg" align="left" type="full"]51635._xfImport[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Thermal error fans running high
threads.message:
P-Bus reported as 12.19V is no good.
Check real voltage on the board (F7040).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Thermal error fans running high
threads.message: It's a hair under 12V according to the multimeter.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Thermal error fans running high
threads.message: Check that voltage without battery connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Thermal error fans running high
threads.message: It goes up to 12.56V with the battery disconnected though.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Thermal error fans running high
threads.message:
I had a look in the area near the SMC where I already ran a jumper wire and replaced a couple of resistors and found that the trace from pin 1 of <TRANSISTOR>Q5030</TRANSISTOR> to <RESISTOR>R5033</RESISTOR> was broken so I ran a jumper wire and now with the battery and charger connected I'm getting 12.3V on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. The fans are behaving normally now and the failing thermal test in ASD now passes. The 12.3V on PPBUS still seems low. Do you think it's something worth still investigating?

Thanks a lot for all your help as usual :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Thermal error fans running high
threads.message: Actually, when I booted into macos, istat menus reports the ppbus @ 12.56V but it was reading a little high before.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Thermal error fans running high
threads.message:
Your multimeter can show erroneous value.
If SMC detects 12.56V should charge and recognize the battery; check that.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Thermal error fans running high
threads.message: Yeah it charges and recognises the battery just fine. All the ASD tests pass just fine now. Thanks again for your help. Can mark this one as solved.
